columns.text: In this exercise, we will calculate how much we will have in one year and two years if we invest one dollar in an investment that pays 0.67% monthly.

To determine the value of the dollar from our investment after one year and two years, we will calculate the future value of the investment.

The future value is the value of particular cash at a future date. The future value considers the present value multiplied by the factor of the rate and period. The computation of future value can be expressed with the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Future value} &= PV\times(1 + i)^t\
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which represent the present value\
$i$, which refers to the discount rate \
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Let's first calculate the dollar value after one year.

In this calculation, we will consider the following details:

| Particulars   |           |
|---------------|-----------|
| Present value | $1 |
| Period        | 12 (Months)        |
| Rate          | 0.67%        |

Next, determine the value of the dollar investment after two years.

In this calculation, we will consider the following details:

| Particulars   |           |
|---------------|-----------|
| Present value | $1 |
| Period        | 24 (Months)        |
| Rate          | 0.67%        |
To conclude, after one year, a $1 in an investment with 0.67% interest is $1.08 and $1.17 for two years, we determined the values by calculating the future value of the investments.
